message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Deep reinforcement learning based mobile robot navigation: A review
Paper Abstract: Navigation is a fundamental problem of mobile robots, for which Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) has received significant attention because of its strong representation and experience learning abilities. There is a growing trend of applying DRL to mobile robot navigation. In this paper, we review DRL methods and DRL-based navigation frameworks. Then we systematically compare and analyze the relationship and differences between four typical application scenarios: local obstacle avoidance, indoor navigation, multi-robot navigation, and social navigation. Next, we describe the development of DRL-based navigation. Last, we discuss the challenges and some possible solutions regarding DRL-based navigation.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "Mobile robot." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.(no content)Mobile robotics is usually considered to be a subfield of robotics and information engineering.

## Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.(no content)The controller is generally a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

## Applications

Mobile robots are widely used across various industries:

- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

## Research and Development

Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

I've completed a web search for "Mobile robot." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.(no content)Mobile robotics is usually considered to be a subfield of robotics and information engineering.

## Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.(no content)The controller is generally a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

## Applications

Mobile robots are widely used across various industries:

- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

## Research and Development

Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

Web search results for query: "Multi-agent system"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Talk:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Template:Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"Java Agent Development Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_Agent_Development_Framework"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about multi-agent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.

## Key Capabilities

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Components and Structure

Multi-agent systems consist of agents and their environment. Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents, however, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Key Characteristics

Agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, and autonomous, with decentralization where no agent is designated as controlling. Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Related Research

The International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) is the leading scientific conference for research in the areas of artificial intelligence, autonomous agents, and multiagent systems, annually organized by the International Foundation for Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems.

Web search results for query: "Deep reinforcement learning"

Links: [{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Fine-tuning (deep learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fine-tuning_(deep_learning)"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Policy gradient method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Policy_gradient_method"},{"title":"Learning automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_automaton"},{"title":"Machine learning in physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_in_physics"},{"title":"Learning rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_rate"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of deep reinforcement learning:

## Definition and Core Concept

Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning.(no content)Deep RL incorporates deep learning into the solution, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

## Capabilities

Deep RL algorithms are able to take in very large inputs (e.g. every pixel rendered to the screen in a video game) and decide what actions to perform to optimize an objective (e.g. maximizing the game score).

## Applications

Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare. More specifically, in robotics, it has been used to let robots perform simple household tasks and solve a Rubik's cube with a robot hand.

## Historical Milestones

Beginning around 2013, DeepMind showed impressive learning results using deep RL to play Atari video games using a deep convolutional neural network to process 4 frames RGB pixels (84x84) as inputs, with all 49 games learned using the same network architecture and with minimal prior knowledge.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning reached another milestone in 2015 when AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board.

## Key Techniques

There is a distinction between model-based and model-free reinforcement learning, which refers to whether the algorithm attempts to learn a forward model of the environment dynamics.

I've completed a web search for "Robot navigation". Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Overview

Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.(no content)A robot requires a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation to navigate effectively.

## Types of Navigation Systems

There are two main categories of mobile robot navigation:

1. **Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs)**: Autonomous mobile robots are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.

2. **Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs)**: An automated guided vehicle follows along marked long lines or wires on the floor, or uses radio waves, vision cameras, magnets, or lasers for navigation.

## Navigation Techniques

Several navigation approaches exist:

- **Vision-Based Navigation**: Vision-based navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finder and photometric cameras using CCD arrays, to extract the visual features required to the localization.

- **SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping)**: Some robot navigation systems use simultaneous localization and mapping to generate 3D reconstructions of their surroundings.

Moss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cynthia_F._Moss"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about obstacle avoidance:

## Overview

Obstacle avoidance is the capability of a robot or an autonomous system/machine to detect and circumvent obstacles in its path to reach a predefined destination.(no content)This technology plays a pivotal role in various fields, including industrial automation, self-driving cars, drones, and even space exploration.

## Detection Methods

One of the most common approaches to obstacle avoidance is the use of various sensors, such as ultrasonic, LiDAR, radar, sonar, and cameras.(no content)These sensors allow an autonomous machine to do a simple 3 step process: sense, think, and act. They take in inputs of distances in objects and provide the robot with data about its surroundings enabling it to detect obstacles and calculate their distances.

## Key Techniques

**Path Planning Algorithms**: Path Planning Algorithms are critical for optimally calculating and routing collision-free paths. These algorithms take into account the robot's position, destination, and the locations of obstacles in the environment. They take and store this information to map out an area, and then use that map to calculate the fastest possible route to a specific destination.(no content)Popular path-planning algorithms include A* (A-star), Dijkstra's algorithm, and Rapidly-exploring Random Trees (RRT).

**Machine Learning**: With artificial intelligence (AI), an autonomous machine can figure out a path to get to its destination, but can also learn to adapt to a rapidly changing environment at the same time.

**Dynamic Window Approach**: The dynamic window approach is an online collision avoidance strategy for mobile robots developed by Dieter Fox, Wolfram Burgard, and Sebastian Thrun in 1997. Unlike other avoidance methods, the dynamic window approach is derived directly from the dynamics of the robot, and is especially designed to deal with the constraints imposed by limited velocities and accelerations of the robot.

## Applications

The rise of autonomous vehicles has led to their use for public transports as a cheaper alternative to hiring drivers, while also removing possible human error. Large corporations use obstacle avoidance when it comes to their automated industrial systems, which replace the need for workers and reduces the amount of mistakes made.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Perfect! I have successfully completed the extraction and classification task. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Extraction Summary

**Paper Type:** Survey - This paper reviews existing DRL methods and frameworks for mobile robot navigation rather than proposing new techniques.

**Key Entities Extracted:**

1. **Deep reinforcement learning** (method) - The core technique reviewed for robot navigation
2. **Mobile robot** (task) - The primary domain/subject of the survey
3. **Robot navigation** (task) - The fundamental problem DRL is applied to
4. **Obstacle avoidance** (task) - One of four typical application scenarios (local obstacle avoidance)
5. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - Relevant to the multi-robot navigation scenario

All entities have been:
- Linked to their corresponding Wikipedia articles
- Classified with appropriate entity types
- Marked with "uses" relation (since this is a survey reviewing existing work)
- Given clear relevance descriptions

The validation script confirmed that all requirements are met:
- ✅ Paper type correctly set to "survey"
- ✅ All 5 triples include proper Wikipedia URLs
- ✅ Entity types are valid
- ✅ Relations are correctly specified
- ✅ All validation checks passed

- [Obstacle avoidance - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obstacle_avoidance)
